El Arish.
Intermittent fever has broken out at El
Arish.
H. M. S. "Carnarvon."
The British cruiser "Carnarvon" arrived at Alexandria at midday to day.
Execution.
Mohamed Ahmed was hanged on Thursday at Assiout prison for murder.
The Shoubra Crime.
The French Consular Court at Cairo has decided to send Albert Paillard to be tried at Aix.
The Ayloula Tax.
The Government has decided to suppress this tax from the 1st prox. It brought in L.E. 40,000 annually to the Treasury.
A Deserter.
A deserter from the Hellenic Navy who had set up as a grocer at Alexandria, was lately identified, and is shortly to be sent off to Greece.
Opening of Semiramis Hotel.
The inauguration ceremony in connection with the opening of the new Semiramis Hotel, Cairo, will take place on January 17, when a ball will be held.
Streets "Up."
The obstacle races organised by the Tanzim are in tall swing in the Place el Kazendar between the Eden Palace Hotel and Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi's.
A Fire.
Last night a fire broke out in a timber store at Alexandria belonging to Messrs. Karam, bat the Fire Brigade succeeded in extinguishing it before extensive damage was done.
Five Days Adrift.
The Hellenic S.8. Emanuel has reached Salina, in tow of another Hellenic steamer. She was adrift for five days on the Black Sea. The Emanuel is the property of a Syra thip-
owner.
Spiritualistio Seance.
An interesting séance is to be given tomorrow at the Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, by the Door-Lebane troupe, when the latest novelties in spiritualism and hynoptism will be shown.
Telephone Company of Egypt
The employment of girls by this company is at present in the experimental stage, and a sort of school is being tried in Cairo. The fatare promises something in that direction in Cairo and here.
Covernment Concessions.

A committee has been formed to examine petitions for Government concessions and monopolies. The members of the committee are Chitty Bey, Mr. Mitchell Innee, Mr. Rocca Serra, and a delegate of the P. W. D.
Counoll of Disoipline.

A Council of Discipline is sitting at the Alexandria Gouvernorat in order to investigate some serious charges against M. Cara- Biello,, the mamour of the Attarin Kism, who has been temporarily suspended from his duties.
Creek Cenerosity.

Lady Zervadachi, of Alexandria, her mother, Mrs. Alexandra Mavrogordato, and her brother, Mr. Theodore Mavrogordato, have given three donations representing a total of about Fre. 460,000 (L.T. 20,000) to the Greek Orthodox benevolent institutions of Constantinople.
Coal Imports.

For the year up to December 20 the imports of coal at Alexandria were 1,222,845 tons. Of these 663,818 tons were Welsh, 205,692 tons Newcastle, 112,549 tons Scotch, 179,270 tons Yorkshire, and 61,516 tons other qualites. The total for the same period last year was 1,022,240 tons.
Linotypes in Egypt.

We must congratulate our Cairo confrère the "Bourse Egyptienne," on its enterprise, for it is the first daily newspaper to be printed by the linotype in Egypt, and in its new form it presents a very smart appearance. Mr. Boutigny, the proprietor of the newspaper, deverses success for his enterprise in introduoing this invention to the local newspaper world.
Creek Tobacco for Egypt.

The Greek tobacco imports for Egyptian cigarettes have been high this year for the following reasons: There was a small crop in Greece and Turkey this year, but large stocks from the formor crop remained to be disposed of. Four million okes of tobacco had arrived here from Greece up to the end of November, which is 500,000 okes above last year's figures. The Alexandria tobacco merchants have increased the price from P.T. 10 to P.T. 12 per oke for the best quality, and from P.T. 7 to P.T. 8 for the second quality.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
div.p: LEGAL OPINION.

Yesterday the Bar Council of the Mixed Courts arrived at a decision on the subject of Lord Cromer's proposal of consolidating the various jarisdictions now prevailing in Egypt. Lord Cromer recently asked the Council to give its opinion on this most important question, and the decision has consequently been awaited with considerable interest. The Council are of opinion that the unification of the jurisdictions is advisible, but that it could be based on the system followed in the creation of the Mixed Courts.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Yesterday the Khedive paid a visit to the Egyptian Army Hospital at Abbassieh, accompanied by Liwa Watson Pasha.
In the afternoon his Highness received Lord Cromer, who presented Dr. Armstrong, of St. Thomas's Hospital, and Mr. Wells, of the Department of Mines.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: We understand that the special commission formed under the auspices of the Legislative Council, under the presidency of Chawarbi Pasha, has completed its labours. Its report, which deals with the gaffir question, will shortly be made public.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Three persons have been admitted to Nag- Hamali Hospital suffering from pneumonic plague, and four fatal cases were recorded there yesterday.
A native workman was found dead in his house at Ras el Tin yesterday. Death was due to bubonic plague.
A fresh case of pneumonic plague has been admitted to Tala hospital, and one death has occurred there in hospital from the same source.

div.head: THE BAD WEATHER.
div.p: Alarming rumours have been rife at Alexandria as to the safety of the S.S. Alexandra, of the Hadji Daoud Company, which ought to have arrived here some days ago from the Piras. A telegram has been received at the office of the Company from Crete announcing that the steamer had taken refuge at Candia owing to the terrible storm that it had encountered on its voyage.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CIGARETTE EXPORTS.
div.p: The total export of Egyptian cigarettes for November was 39,811 kilor, a falling off of 20,664 kilos as compared with the exports of November, 1905, which were 60,475 kilos. For the year to November 30 the total was 543,807 kilos, as against 630,046 kilos for the same period of last year. Of this total of 39,811 kilos, above mentioned, 7,421 kilos went to Great Britair, 12,197 kilos to Germany, and 2,399 kilos to France. In each case there was a falling off, as compared with the exports of last November, when, for instance, Germany bought 29,157 kilos. The value of this November's exports, was L.E. 31,847.

div.head: CONSULAR COURT CONVICTION.
div.p: ESCAPADE OF A TARBOUCHE.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Thursday.

Great outirsity was evinced by a crowd of a few hundred persons this morning outside His Britannic Majesty's Consular Court at the alarmingly drastic measures adopted by the police authorities against two passengers from the S.S. Denbighshire, which arrived at Port Said about 10 o'clock this morning, homeward bound. From the result of enquiries, it seems that one of the two passengers referred to, had, in the course of their sight-seeing, inadver- tantly collided with a police functionary, whose tarbouche, reputed to be not quite large enough for its owner's head, fell to the ground. This disaster, it appears, forms the fundamental ground on which the charge was raised and terminated in the visitors being placed before His British Majesty's Consul General, Mr. D. A. Cameron, to stand their trial for drunken ness and assault.

One of the unhappy individule, who was far too excited to be capable of what might be considered reasonable action, resorted to measures which in calmer moments might seem the reverse, but under the circumstances were not unnatural, and doubtless relieved his strained feelings somewhat. The Consul-General very summarily dealt with the offenders, passing sentence of seven days without the option of a fine on one of the accused, who was safely transported under a strong escort of police commanded by Lieut. Macintyre to the native prison, where he was safely lodged before the sun had reached its zenith.

The S. Denbighshire sailed a few hours later without its fall complement of passengers, the general impression amongt the remaining passengers before starting being one of thankfulness that they had escaped from Port Said and an expression of sympathy for his Majesty's loyal subjects resident in Port Said.
"Venus" arrives.
Friday.
H.M.S. Venus arrived here this morning after a few days gun practice and a short visit to Alexandria.
H.M.S. FOX AT SUEZ.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Saez, Friday.
H.M.S. Fox arrived at Suez from the Persian
Gulf last night. She will proceed home in a few days as soon as her relief arrives.

div.head: INTERESTING LIBEL CASE.
div.p: The charge of libel alleged by M. George Vayssié, pablicist, against M. G. Costagliola, rinter of the newspaper "Bosphore," has been dismissed by the French Consular Court, Cairo, which has just rendered its verdict. It was case of tit-for-tat. M. Vayasié, in the "Journal da Caire," of the 9th May, had aconsed M. Zariffa in the matter of an article written by the latter in the "Bosphore" on the subject of the Capitulations, of plagiarism perpetrated at the expense of the "Journal des Débats." To this M. Santorelli retorted on the morrow by an article whose terms M. Vayssié considered so defamatory, that he took action against Messrs. Zariffa and Santorelli before the Mixed Tribunals, and M. Costagliola, before the French Tribunal, as responsible printer.

The case was heard on the 14th inst.; Article 42 of the Law of July 29, 1881, was more than once invoked; and as the Court held that M. Costagliola could not be considered as the person chiefly responsible, the charge alleged against him was dismissed with costs.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.) La reprise s'accentue largement aujourd'hui avec affaires importantes en Cassa di Soonto, Estates, Comptoir et Crédit 'Franco-Egyptien. On a également traité, quoique dang des proportions plus restreintes, la National Bank, l'Investment, l'United, l'Helouan et les Ritz. La Cassa di Sconto bénéficie d'une avance de 5 francs à 276 l'ancienne et 271 la nouvelle; l'action Comptoir progresse de 7 9/16 à 7 11/16 et la part de fondateur de 70 à 81, soit 20 livres de hausse pour cette dernière en deux séances, en raison de la prochaine émission; le Crédit Franco-Egyptien monte de 6 1/4 à 6 5/16, l'Agricole de 9 5/8 à 9 11/16 et la National Bank de 28 5/16 à 28 3/8.On échange l'United entre 1 5/32 et 1 3/16, l'Hélouan entre 1 et 1 1/32 et les Ritz Hotels aux environs de 1 9/16. Les certificats au porteur des actions Ritz Hotels seront à la disposition des intéressés dans les premiers jours de janvier chez M. E. Kerr, de la maison E. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt, où l'on pourra les obtenir, moyennant libération complète des titres.

En hausse également la Béhéra de 40 3/4 à 42 1/4, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire de 280 à 281, les Markets de 29/6 à 30/9 acheteurs, la Privilégiée Bière du Caire de 184 à 135, la Salt & Soda de 24 à 24/9, les Nungovich Hotels de 21 3/8 à 22 1/2 vendeurs, la Nile. Land de 18 à 18 3/8, et l'Union Foncière de 6 5/16 à 6 7/16 acheteurs.

Par contre, l'Alexandria Water fléchit de 1313/16 à 13 3,4, vendeurs, les Cotton Mills de 6/6 à 6/3, la Delta Land de 4 11/16 à 4 5/8 vendeurs, l'Investment de 1 1/2 à 1 15/32 la Land Bank de 8 3/4 à 8 11/16, l'Allotment de 3 7/8 à 3 13/16 l'action et de 155 à 150 la part de fondatear.
La tendance da moment est excellente. Tout le monde est aux schats.

div.head: CAIRO RACES.
div.p: FIRST WINTER MEETING.
SECOND DAY'S RACING.

We in Cairo can again congratulate ourselves on, another excellent day's racing, and we hope our sporting visitors are equally satisfied. The attendance yesterday was larger than on Wednesday, and although we were again sorry to see the Khedive's stand empty, the grounds, containing many beautiful ladies in beautiful dresses, locked charming. It is perhaps an improvement huying the band in front. We were glad that the horse am- balance exhibited in front of the grand stand I was not required; this latter is not a thing of beauty, but, alas, is sometimes very
necessary.

In the first race, Abou Nadara again showed his many admirers what a real good little horse he is. It is worthy of note that on the first day, round the course, he was carrying 11 st. 7 lb. and Fadghan 8 st. 1 lb., whereas yesterday Fadghan carried 8 st. 1 lb. and Abou Nadara 9 st. 6 lb. The handicapper seems to have hit it off nicely. Fenwick had bad luck in the Steeple Chase, and might have played the waiting game a little longer with success. In the third race Kawkab had a bad start and never made up the lost ground. Rainbow ran a very game pony.

In the fourth race Rejected had bad luck, and being interfered with at the last corner, came to grief. Lady Meldrum was, however, leading at the time, and Rejected would not have had it all his own way. Lady Meldrum is a 3-years-old filley by Tarporley, dam Aboyne. As we know, Tarporley's stock are doing great things in England now. We predict a successful career for Lady Meldrum, as she has only been five weeks in the country. The fifth race was a badly ran race, the time being very slow. Shour is a beautifu'ly bred little pony, and winning against some very high-class ponies, his sporting owner may be warmly congratulated. The sixth race was ran in very good time.
The betting was on a considerable scale, the Pari Matuel earning nearly £200 in their share of the betting, which means that some £2,000 changed hands.

div.head: WHERE THE GOLD IS!
div.p: The following little episode which happened only a short time ago in one of our country villages will be read with interest by those who are daily enquiring as to where is all the gold that is constantly arriving in this country from Europe.

A certain well-known firm of merchants had occasion to send their collector into the country to recover some payments in the ordinary course of business. He arrived at the house of one of the firm's customers (a quondam fellah, now an enriched land-owner). Here he was met by the master, who showed him, with much satisfaction, new) house he had recently bailt on his property. He took him below the ground floor, which he had arranged as an office in which he transacted the affairs of his farm. In due course he expressed his willingness to settle his account with the firm in' question, and for this purpose he essayed to open an English safe which had been sank in the ground in a corner of the room. On the safe being opened there was exposed to view several bags of sovereigns, with some of which bags he discharged his debt amounting to some few thousands to the collector. The interesting part of the answer to the question is now to come. The collector, on taking his bags of money, discovered that they were sealed, labelled, and dated as originally sent out by the National Bank three years ago and his bags had not since been opened, but were in the same condition as originally sent out by the Bank! After the debt was defrayed there remained several more bags of a similar nature ia the safe, all this resulting, of course, in a loss of several hundred pounds to the owner by way of unearred interest. This is no isolated case, as we are constantly hearing of similar hoardings from different parts of the country. Until the native learns to appreciate the value of the tanks as safe custodians of his gold, we shall annually require more and more gold to pay for the enormous increase in land and produce, such as cotton, cereals, etc., and Europe will therefore be called upon accordingly.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Augustus d'Arenberg, Chairman of the board of directors of the Suez Canal Company, is arriving at Port Said on Monday next by the North Germans Lloyd's S.S. Gneisensu.

It said that the dowager Lady Ashburton, and her fon, Mr. Alexander Ashburton, will sper d several months in Egypt this winter. Lady Ashburton, who has been for many years a widow, spends most of her time at Metchet Court, near Romsey, though she still keeps up her house in Cadogan Square, where she usually passes a part of the London season. Captain the Hon. Gay Ashburton, of the Coldstream Guards, is on his way to Cairo, accompanied by his "wite.
Lady Colvin is among the distinguished visitors to Egypt who will spent Christmas in Cairo.
M. Klobukowski, the new French Diplo matic Agent and Consul General in Cairo, arrived yesterday at Alexandria from Earope and proceeded to Cairo by the noon train.

Mr. James Duckworth, J.P., Liberal member of Parliament for Stockport, who has been advised to winter abroad on account of his health, which has of late been, far from satisfactory is coming to Egypt,and it is probable that he will also visit the Sadan, spending a few weeks at Khartoum.

Mrs. Robert Goelet, of the well-known American millionaire family, is arriving shortly at Port Said on her steam yacht the "Nahma." Mrs. Goelet is on her way from New York and will pick up her yacht at Marseilles. From Egypt she is proceeding to Bombay on a visit to India.

Mr. Ernest Sharp, of Boston, the well-known American singer, has arrived with his wife at Shepheard's Hotel on a pleasure tour around the world. This remarkable artist has kindly offered to sing for the visitors of Shepheard's Hotel on Christmas Eva in the main hall. Mr. Ernest Sharpe, possesses a very fine basso profundo voice, and has met everywhere with the greatest success.

Madame J. Pesmazogla has given 25.000 drackme to the Mayor of Athens for the poor in memory of her late husband. "Le Monde Hellenique" states that the magnificent floral tribute sent on the occasion of her husband's faneral were sold by order of his widow for the benefit of Greek refugees from Bulgaria and Roumelia.
Mrs. H. de Vries has given £20 to the Jewish Orphange at Cairo and a similar sum for the purchase of usefal articles for the orphans' school.
We regret to announce the death of M. Jules Ducros, one of the doyens of the French Colony at Cairo.

Mr. Geo. Vivian Vernon, we are sorry to hear, is still at the Deaconesses' Hospital, where he has bean for the last month. Previous to going to hospital he was nearly a month ill at his home at Ramleh. We trust soon to hear better news of his health.

div.head:
BRITAIN AND GERMANY.
COMMUNITY OF INTERESTS.
COMBINED ACTION IN AFRICA.

div.p: The Berliner Lokal Anzeiger" announces from London that negotiations have actually taken place between representatives of the German and British Governments with regard to the question of preventing rebel natives of South-West Africa from orossing into British territory, and also with reference to Germany's request to permit provisions and monitors for her troops to be sent through Cape Colony. These two measures would be advantageous to the troops and agreeable to the Commanderin-Chief in German South West Africa. The Governor, Herr De Lindequist, is also taking part in the negotiations, the ground for which was prepared a long time ago, between King Edward, Sir Edward Grey, and Count Metternich.
The British Government has already repeatedly insisted on the community of German and British interests in South West Africa for the good of civilisation.
(Reuter)

div.head: MARTHE BRANDES.
div.p: "Les Tenailles"-it might be called "L'Impasse," for that matter-is wholly modern, and yet almost Greek in its relentlessness, it is a return to the sternest "Adanké," the looked prison-house in which the prisoners mast live and lament antil death release them; they may be innocent or guilty, they are miserable, and equal thereby. The note is, in & sense, that of "L'Amoureuse," withont ite hope and possibility, without its misunderstand ing whereby at least a chance was given that could lighten the darkness. Fergan, the husband, is opinionated, always right, master in his own house, by all that his power, and the law, social, moral, and otherwise, can give him. Irene, his wife, married young, has developed, has struggled for her owo temperament and personality and spiritual freedom. At last, vanquished by that uncompromising Wall of tyranny, she is driven to think of. thea to long for, bodily freedom. Fergan refuses to separate : she gives herself to Tavernier Consumptive. She h49 & son, Davernier dies: she livas for the son, until Pergan propose to send the boy to school. She, in deadly motherly fear for her one love, refases, and declares the truth. Fergan now asks for divoros. She refuses in her turn; and they are left to adore the rest of their years together, she to forget her shame in all she might have had, and to watch her boy live-or die; he to go through the tortures of 000 whose righteousness, too narrow and too ruthless, has brought its owo penalty, as keen and on-baman as Artemis' doom op Hippolytus and hi: house.

Mlle Brandès and M. Rousselle were again at their height, worthy of one another and of the play. Irene was created by her. It would be almost impossible to imagine another in her place, for depth and trath of rendering. For M. Rousselle the part was different to the four others he has so far played : and again he show ad what an artist he is: his personality changed entirely to that of Fergan. Every tone and every movement, the least as well as the greatest, was that of the overbearing potentate, justified in all why did. They are a wonderful couple. Of course, one sees instantly that there is a difference: he merges himself in his part, wholly, is unrecognisable from the night before, is the character he played, and no other. She is always Marthe Brandès, and yet she is Irene, or Dora, or Francillon : who gives the whole personality of the character, and the whole personality of her own wonderful and subtle self at one and the same time. One might, for an instant, ba critical with Rassalle, watch for a wrong note, compare him with what one thinks he should b3; bat har, - lovar. Oje watches bar, not for what she might do, but for what she is doing and is going to do, still, passionate, raptarone, forgiving, in all th: moody that hold as and our memory,

The others did not make a great show, Mme Laare way the b39"perhape. André Hall was far too cold, and conventional; he had sufficient art, bat no reality. Imagine Le Bargy in the part ! But at least I will say that many others would have made it ride colong. He hardly did that, he was at worst awkward, unable to feel or simulate strongly the passion that should have been devouring him.
He was André Hall, a good and tried actor, never Davernier, the consumptive, who ze whole being should tremble with the great trust and then the great abandonment of tbe woman ha worships.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain and Brevet Major (local Lieutenant Colonel) B. A. Stanton, Governor of Khartoum Province, has been promoted to substantive field rapk on the half-pay liet, to which he went from the Oxfordshire Light Infantry on completing ten years' service with the Egyptian Army. Stanton Bey has shared in every campaign in which the Khedive's troops bavo been engaged since 1896: Dongola Expedition, 1896; Nile Expedition, 1897; Nile Expedition, 1898, including Atbara and Omdarman, and the Nile Expedition, 1899. His rewards were four mentions in despatches, Egyptian medal with six collapse, British modal and 3rd Class Medjidie.

The War Office has ruled that colour sergeant instructors of maskotry are to reckon seniority as colour sergeants from Jane let, 1904, the date on which that appointment was authorised, and not from the date on which they were appointed sergeant instructors of musketry. This order, no doubt, will allay some of the difficulties of the question.

The Army Council, it is announced, bas decided to alter and review the regulations for the examination of officers in tactical fitness for command. No specific indication as to the lines of alteration has yet been made.

div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Qu'est ce que c'est BOVRIL?
BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
BOVRIL répare l'organisme fatigué.

div.head: Cotons.
div.p: La tenue de marché pendant la matinée de samedi et l'on vertore de lundi matin, et la hausse de 3/4 de tallari qui en été la conSéquence, ont constitué pour nous abe-surprise aussi grande que désagréable, et pour un moment nous nous sommes demandé si nous n'avions pas la berlus quand nous avons écrit vendredi dernier que le marché était hésitant et la tendance pour la baiese ! Mais, réflexion faite, nous nous sommes rendu compte qu'après tout Alexandria ne pouvait raisonnablement laisser passer, sans en profiter, l'occasion propice qoi ne présentait à elle, et qui consistait dans les achats des grandes têtes qui ont voulu se livrer à des opérations d'arbitrage, en achetant de Mars et en vendant du Novembre, et ceux de la spéculation cairote, qui avaient décidé que le coton égyptien était pour rios et qu'on saurait l'imposer à la consommation même à 80 talaris ; notre impression était aussi que le mouvement auquel nous assistons ne pouvait, être que tout à fait passager.

Cette façon d'envisager, les choses s'est trouvée être juste, car, dès que les acteurs 80 sont arrêtés la réaction a commencé et cette fois la baisse a été aussi rapide que la hausse qui l'avait précédée, étant donné que dans l'espace de vingt-quatre heures elle s'est élevés à tallari 1 9/16. Seulement, notre satisfaction, toute platonique, de voir nos prévisions be réaliser n'a pas été de longue durée, le cours de 20 5/16. ayant sa le don de faire rentrer en Boène de découvert tôt ensuite les haussiers derechef, ce qui nous a valu on renouvellement, plas modéré cependant, des manoeuvres ayant pour but de pousser les prix. Dans tous les cas, ce qui est un fait, c'est que depuis lors, la fermeté n'a cessé de régner et que la posture finale dels hautaine a en lieu sur la opte de 20 15/16 pour le Mars.
Comme résumé donc, c'est une baisse de 3/16 sur vendredi dernier, on recal de 15/16 da prix maximum pratiqué lundi dernier, mais une baisse de 15/8 du point le plus bas de Mardi.

En elle-même, cette amélioration de 5,8 de tallari n'aurait rien d'extraordinaire, compara. tivement surtout à ces fluctuante violentes auxquelles nous sommes habitués depuis quelque tempe, mais en l'absence de toute oh DBE pouvant la justifier, n'est-on pas excusable en disant que franchement le bon sens perd trop Boivent ses droits à notre corbeille! A quel résultat espère-t-on arriver avec ces continuelles mai avres 1 À égorger le découvert ? Mais il n'existe plus, et s'il y a des vendeurs en blanc, on ne les trouvera que parmi ces faiseurs qui se risquent à vendre en quantités limitées quand il y a emballement sur le marché et qui profitent des accalmies pour se racheter. Quant au commerce, que quelques exaliós disent vouloir accoler à foros de loi faire payer des différence sur les contrats, mais il ne fait que ropa:ser à la spéculation les contrats qu'il avait en couverture de ses engagements pour l'Europe, et n'est parlement vendeur contre marchandise

en magasin, ni les nécessités, ni la nature de . son travail de cette année, ni les conditions monétaires de la place depuis deux mois ne lui ayant permis les arbitrages qu'il fait habituellement dans le courant de la campagne.

Il ne nous reste par conséquent que la filature, mais soT de point nous avons déjà exposé 06 qu'il fallait en penser et en définitive Nous arrivons à cette conclusion que tout ce que la apboplation est en train de faire est factice, que tous ces achats et ventes de chaque jour sont un pur jeu de navette entre spéculateurs mêmes, chacun cherchant à sortir aux dépens de son voisin, voire de 100 copain au besoin, et que dans ces conditions et à moins que l'imprévu ne vienne an ver la situation, il ne reste qu'un ori à jeter et c'est celui de "Gare au dernier détenteur, c'est lui paiera les pots cassés.

Le jeu d'intérêt montré par le commerce depuis mercredi pour les affaires en contrats vieille récolte a certainement pui à l'activité du marché qui n'a été, en effet, que occasionnelle ; par contre, le novembre a attiré son attention, car, quoique l'on en dise, la file ture a fait de nouveaux achats pour la prochaine récolte. Au fond il n'y a rien de bien ito portant, mais en somme plus d'un conSommateur cherche À faire une moyenne en mélangeant les cours de l'ancienne et de la nouvelle récolte, ne fût-ce que pour les premiers mois. D'ailleure, la prospérité de L'industrie cotonnière est telle sur le conti. beat, que de l'Allemagne du moins on affirme que les filateurs sont à même de vendre leurs és pour livraison jusqu'à': la fin Mars 1908 !! Si le fait se généralise, la perspective pourra revenir on ne plus alléchante pour nos cultivateurs qui, une fois de plus, vont obtenir de Tog prix pour leur récolte. Tant mieux pour
pays ! Espérons seulement que la spooler, tout en s'engageant de préférence sur la roubine récolte qui lui offre plus de chances e bénéfices avec le cours de 18 talaria, que

Juillet avec celui de 22, n'ira pas gâter ses affaires on forçant la porte, d'autant plus que dans le pivesso actuel elle trouvera très pro ablemont l'agriculteur même disposé à assurer De partie de sa production. . De l'Amérique on continue à nous prêcher hausse en se basant sur les achate de la nature, mais de son côté le mouvement de la récolte ne cesse de peser sur le marché.

'ailleurs, vous sommes dans la période de calme annuel et il y a manque de spéculation; to est vraisemblablement à cette instance ce l'on doit l'indifférer ce avec lequel a été cor oili le Cen 808 Barean, seal fait intéres. ant de la semaine, donnant l'égrenage au 13 courant comme étant de balles 11.099.000 contre 9.282.000 en 1905. On ajoute, la russie, ne le dit rapport correspond tout bonnement l'attente générale.

Notre marché da disponible est moins actif depuis quelques jours et pour ce qui est les prix, il ne fait que enivre, plus ou moins, les fluctuations des contrats : Bellemont tous les genres ne sont pas traités sur le même pied, les Mit Affitti fios étant bien tous,

tandis qu'à partir de Good et au-dessous il y a recul de T|4* 5/8"de tallari. Les Provenances Haute-Egypte, pon abondantes sur le marché et recherchées, n'ont perdu que 1/4 de tallari. - Les Ioannovich sont dans ce même dernier as, tandis que les Atassi restent inchangés.
Les exportations ont été fortes, soit Balles 36000 contre Bal 25000. La semaine pro
haine sera moine grosse, mais l'année dernière aussi vous n'avons eu pour la même période que 1600) Balles.

On n'est pas d'accord sur les probabilités de Janvier et chacun juge d'après ses propres engageante. De l'ensemble des informations cependant il ressort qu'il sera sensiblement plus réduit que Décembre, qui a été d'ana importance exceptionnelle.

Liverpool a fiói par revenir à l'ancien oliebe de 160 et 200 Balles par jour pour les ventes en égyptiens disponible, et avec l'augmentation constante du stock dans le dit port, cela Semble quelque peu il qu'étant. Ea attendant, les Anglais n'ont pas l'air de trop se soucier de notre marché.
Pour ce qui est des prix, le spot a é!é mieux traité que les facteurs, le premier ayant gagné 1/18 à la cote de 10 5/16, tandis que le Janvier perd 12/64 au cours de 10 2/64..

Les Américains ont, par contre, été plus actifs avec une marche des cours absolument différente de celle des égyptiens, 19 disponible ayant fioi à 5.69, soit 10 points de baisse contre une baRBe de 6 points pour les futurs, refpro tivement côtés 5.43 pour le Janvier Février et 3.47 pour le Mai Juin.

Le mouvement de notre récolte est toujours formidable : l'avance sur l'année dernière est de 900,000 cantars, mais l'excédent de notre stick n'est que de 300 OCO, les exportations ayant, de leur cô é, absorbé 460.000 cantars de plus qu'en 1905.

div.head: Graines de Coton.
div.p: Les recettes sont toujours forte, mais par contre la demande a quelque peu diminué, les exportations n'étant plus aussi importantes que par le passé. Cette circonstance a permis une certaine augmentation dans le stock.
Quant aux prix do disponible, toute la fe. maine s'est passée sur le cours de P.T. 65 A l'exception d'aujourd'hui, la cote ayant été relevée à P. 66 å cause de la hausse des contrats.

Sur ces derniers les offres sont to jiors Sodas onnelles, mais depuis mercredi un caban. gement en mieux s'est produit sur notre msr olé : il y a un peu plus d'activité et plu, de régularité dans les transactions. Clotaire Pétrier Mars P.C. 70 2/40.

Hull et on peut mieux disposés pour nos 'graine, car elle semble avoir des besoins à couvrir avant l'arrivée de la graine du Bombay dorit les embarquements ont commencé. Elle * payez en dernier lien £ 6.10-pour Décembre. • Les huiles sont calmés, msis Retenues.
Ls graine de lin est réussi dans l'Argentine et det article viendra bientôt entraver la conSommation de notre graine.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIÈRE
div.p: Après une série de séances nulles et en baisse, déterminée par une recrudescence de la crise monétaire sur place, la surcharge d'un grand nombre de positions, l'abstention des acheteurs, l'approche de la redoutable liquidation de fin d'année et la hausse du taux privé d'escompte en Angleterre, une reprise aussi soudaine que inattendue s'est produite hier et s'est fortement accentuée ce matin. La 08088 de ce revirement i Les détenteurs trop faibles, surpris par la baisse, s'étaient tout simplement décidés à passer sous les Porches Citadines des banques et capitalistes reporters. Entre deux maux ils avaient choisi le moindre ou du moins le plus éloigné. Plutôt que de subir une perte immédiate sur des valeurs dans l'avenir desquelles ils avaient une confiance absolue, ils avaient préféré, en payant 30 à 50% de report, voir venir. On parle, on effet, d'une forte poussée pour le mois de janvier. Anesi quantité de positions ont-elles été reportées dans les conditions et pour peu que ce mouvement, continue encore une ou deux séances, la liquidation fin décembre passera sans encombre. Tel un nuage, gros de tempête, de dissipe sans laisser de tracol.

Tout le monde n'a sûrement pas été satisfait de cette solutioN-Beaucoup de capitalistes, petits et groe, guettaient le moment propice pour garnir leurs portefeuilles de titres momentanément dépréciés ; ils escomptait, sans doute, une dégringolade beaucoup plus rémunératrice et surtout plus prolongée. A peine les plus avisés d'entre eux opt-ils en le temps de ramasser quelques centaines d'actions ; car, il ne faut pas se le dissimuler, les affaires ont été très clairsemées durant le courte période de baisse qui vient de sévir,

La reprise qui l'a immédiatement suivie nous ramène sensiblement au même niveau que Vendredi passé et même à un niveau légèrement supérieur, puisque sur une oin quanta jae do valeurs inscrites à la cote officielle de notre bourse, 32 sont en hausse, 15 seulement en baisse et les autres demeurent stationnaire

A Londres, la National Bank perd 1/8 & 98 1/4, la Daïra 1/4 & 17 1/2, la Delta Light 1/8 * 12 1/4,l'Unifiée 1/4 à 102 et le Consolida 5/8 # 86 ; d'autre part, le taux privé d'escompte s'élève de 5 5/8 à 6% et la réserve de la banque tombe de 47 á 38 1/2 %
A Paris, les actions de Sas gagnent 98 fr. & 4530, tandis que le Crédit Foncier Égyptien perd 2 fr. à 781 et la Land Bank of Egypt 2 fr. 221. La rente recalé de 96,17 à 95,20.

La mort inopinée de M. Glymenopoulo & entraîné une dépression considérable pour le groupe de valeurs qu'il dirigeait : Les Tramways d'Alexandrie sont tombés' 209 les Privilégiées et 350 les Dividendes, en perte respective de 15 et 16 franos; Is Building a fléchi de 521/32 à 5 3/8 et le Írast a également faibli de 1 21/32 8 i /8 vendeurs.

Les titres favoris de la spéculation qui avaient eu le plus à souffrir de la réaction du début de la semaine se sont en général Lovés aveo le p!us de vigueur, bénéficiant memp d'une avance sur la clôture de la semaine écoulée : ainsi la Cassa di sconto gagne 6 francs à 271 l'ancienne et 266 la nouvelle, la Delta Land 1/8 8 4 11/16, l'Investment 3/32 à 11/2, les Estates 8/32 8 2 1/, le Comptoir 1/8 l'action 4179/16 et 8 livres la part de fondateur à 70, le Crédit FrancO-Égyptien 1/16 à 6 1/4 et la Barque d'Orient 8 fr. 50 à 135 1/2. L'Urbaine 89 consolide à 7 11/16. L'Agricole et la NatioNal Bank progressent aussi de 1/16 à 9 5/8 et 28 5/16.

En reprise également la Ramleh Railway de 6 3/4 à 6 7/8, les Jouissances Box du Caire de 270 à 280 et les actions de 191 à 129, la Bévéra de 40 4 40 3/4, les Markets de 29 & 29/6, lx Filatore de 93/82 à 3/4, la Dividende Bière d'Alexandrie de 115 117, la Salt & Sods de 28 à 24, l'Ordinaire Khedivial Mail de 39 à 39/6, la Land Bank de '8 11/16188/4, et la part de fondateur Allotment de RT. 135 à PT. 155.
Les pertes les plus sensibles sont de 18 à 12 1/8 sur la Delta Light, 3/8 à 5 578 sar l'Anglo American Nile, 1/4 sur les Nangovich Hotels & 21 3/4, et 6 fr. sur les Sucreries à 70, vendeur,

L Bière da Caire réactionnel aussi de 1 fr. à 134 la Privilégiée et 72 la Dividende, l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier de 1 fr. à 336, le Splendid Hôtels de 1/16 8 4 3/16, le Cheikh Padi de 2 fr. à 108, l'Union Foncière de 1/16 à 6 5/16 et le Badoo di Roma de 1 fr. à 114, vendeurs.
A noter que la plupart de ces valeurs inscrites en baisse ont cependant repris au cours de ces deux dernières séances mais pas suffisamment pour regagner toute l'avant perdue.
Le reste de la côte demeure stationnaire aux cours antérieurs.

A l'assemblée générale ordinaire tontie le 14 courant par les actionnaires de la Khédivial Mail, il a été décidé de distribuer un dividende de 10 % pour l'année finissant le 30 juin. Une assemblée générale extraordinaire est convoquée pour le 31 décembre en vue de l'augmentation projetée da capital à £ 400.000 par la création de 100.000 actions ordinaires nouvelles

Vo conflit existe entre un groupe local d'actionnaires et le conseil londonien d'Administration de la Delts Land. Le groupe en question demande que l'administration effective de la Société soit transférée en Egypte et vent dans ce bat provoquer une assemblée générale extraordinaire. Comme, toutefois, le président da conseil doit venir ici vers la mi. Janvier, il a été convenu qu'on attendrait son arrivée pour engager avec loi des pour parlere et ensuite seulement, s'il y avait lied, prove quoi la convocation d'une assemblée générale.

La Salt and Soda vient de publier son rapport. L'exercice au 31 Août 1906 se oltare par 70.000 livres de bénéfices environ. Après la distribution d'un dividende de LE. 32,906 sox action, soit 7 1/2 %, et de L.B. 2,643 AOX Deferred, le Conseil d'administration propose de reporter à nouveau L.B. 84,534. Cette som me servirait éventuellement à l'extinction projetée des Deferred. L'assemblée, appelée à ra. tifier ce bilan, se réagira le 27 courant.

Les certificats au porteur des actions Ritz Hôtels seront prêts dans les premiers jours de janvier. Les détenteurs d'actions pourront dong Be prévente à partir de cette dati chez M. B. Kerr, de la maison Russell, Kerr & Wyatt, et obtenir des certificats pour le montant de leora lettres de répartition, contre paiement intégral des titres.

Da 2 80 8 janvier doit être opéré le 20. versement de 62 fr. 50 sur l'appel de 125 fr do Crédit Foncier Egyptien. Le 2e. quart soit £1, sur l'Épargne Immobilière est de depuis le 15 décembre. Le dernier quart de L... 1 de la Gbarbieh Land est appelé pont k 31 courant,

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, 21 Décembre 1905. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est toujours renseigné à 6%. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de 1 à 86. L'Uni. fiée est restée avariée a 102. La National Bank a gagné 1 à 28 . La Daïra a perda 1/8 a 17). L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 9, de même que la Delta Light & 12. ?
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptien a rétrogradé de 7 francs & 782. La Banque d'Athènes a avancé de 2 franor a 140 L'Emprunt rose 1906 & passé de 86.6086.80.

Ainsi que nous l'avions fait pressentir hier, la tendance générale du marché s'est fortement améliorée ce matin. La séance a été animée, les transactions ont été nombreuses et il y a à enregistrer une plus value appréciable sur presque toute la côte.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na. tional a gagné plus de 1/4 de livre a 28 1-7/16. L'Agricole a progressé à 9 . La Casa avancé a 369-370. Le Comptoir Financier s'est inscrit à 7 % et sa part a 68. La Banque d'Orient a été mieux tenue a 138. La Banque d'Abyssinie a faibli à 5 5/8.
L'Enterprise and Development est remontée a 13 13/16. La part de fondateur Immobilière s'est alourdie à 700. L'Union Foncière s'est relevée a 6 7/16 1/8.

L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux, qui a attiré hier à 14 1/4, a débuté aujourd'hui a 14 pour remonter a 14 1/4 et clôturer & 14. On remarque que les personnes généralement bien renseignés continuent à ramasser soignon. sement le flottant, et on s'attend, en Bourse, a des prix plus élevés dans un bref délai. La part de fondateur a été demandée a 105.
Les Jouissances Exo da Caire ont avancé a 280-282. Les Tarifs-Nabas ont été négociés à 4 1/4 et leur part de fondateur entre 20 et 29 livres.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nangovich sont remontés a 21 11/16-3/4. Les Egyptian ont atteint 10:10 1/16. Les National 80 sont raffermis a 4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land, en bonne tende, ont encore bénéficié de 1/16 & 4 5/8-11/16, de même que les Estates a 2 7/16. 1/3. Les New Egyptian se sont consolidés 32 sh. Les Constructions ont avancé a 1 5/811/16. Los Syrian Lands ont 6 é traités & 2 3/16. Les United Lands ont avancé a 1 1/8 et lear part de fondateur a 5 7/8.

A l'occasion des fêtes de Noël il y aura Cessation d'affaires à la Bourse, les lundi 24, mardi 25 et mercredi 26 Décembre 1906, et, a l'occasion du Jour de l'An, le lundi 31 Décembre 1906 et le mardi ler Janvier 1907.
Le Comité de l'honorable Corporation des Agents de change du Caire a adressé, à la date d'hier, la nouvelle lettre circulaire suivante a tous les membres de ladite Corporation :
CORPORATION De Agents De CHANGE
DU CAIRE
Le Caire le 20 Décembre 1906. A MM. les Membres de la "Corporation des Agents de Change" du Caire

Le Comité, dans la séance de ce matin, a fixé pour ce jour de liquidation extraordinaire pour les opérations a terme sur les actions de la Société "Entreprise Immobilières et de Travaux" au prix de L. B. 14, dont le pays. ment sera exigible le samedi 22 courant.
Veuillez en prendre bonne note et agréez M., nos salutations distinguées.
Pour le Comité et par ordre,
Le Président, P. OZIOL. Dont acte.

On nous pose de nouveau, de divers côtés la question de savoir quelle peut être la valeur réelle de la part de la Société civile de la Bourse Khédiviale (1) da Caire, qui continue a être cotée invariablement livres 150 sur le Bulletin officiel de la Corporation des Agents de change da Caire.
La demande est embarrassante ou plutôt délicat, d'autant plus qu'il s'agit ici d'ane oote parement nominale, pour ne pas dire fictive.
Toujours est-il que nous pouvons, Bar S Boréale, satisfaire plus ou moins la curiosité de non correspondants en leur apprenant (s'ils l'ignorent):

D'ape part, que la Société civile de la Bourse du Caire a été créée au capital de Livres 1000 représenté par 100 parts de Livres 10 chacune, et qu'elle a pour tout revenu les droits d'entrée a la Bourse, sous-locations diverses, publicité, etc.

D'autre part, que cette société civile est restés absolument étrangère a l'acquisition du | terrain acheté par la Corporation des Agents de Change du Caire a la Compagnie Immobilière d'Egypte, en vue de la construction d'ape nouvelle Booree.

Or dono, quelle garantie peuvent présenter les parts mentionnées au prix actuel de 150 livres, da moment que la Corporation des Agents de change da Caire ayant payé de ses propres deniers le terrain situé entre les Savoy 'et National Hotele, c'est a elle seule que revient tout le profit dérivant de la plag-valde acquise par ce terrain ? Bi d'autres termes, la Société civile n'a rien a encaisser ou même a espérer de ce chef.
Il nous sembla que poser le problème, o'est le résoudre. | Pour ce qui est de savoir si l'on érigera, on non, une Bourse sur ce terrain, c'est là une question tout a fait à part.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA AND RAMLEH RAILWAY Co. Ltd.
div.p: Assemblee Generale Ordinaire.
AVIS Messieurs les Actionnaires sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Ordinaire le Jeudi 27 Décembre 1906 à 4 heures de relevée, aux Bureaux de la Compagnie à Alexandrie.
L'ordre du jour de cette Assemblée comprend:
2.- Nomination de Censeur pour l'exercice | 1906-1907 et fixation de sa rétribution.
3.- Renouvellement de tous les Membres da Conseil d'Administration conformément aux art. 37 & 39 des statuts, qui sont réali. gibles.

Les Actionnaires porteurs d'au moins 20 actions qui voudraient assister à l'Assemblée ou s'y faire représenter doivent déposer leurs actions & Alexandrie, au siège de la Compagnie, à la National Bank of Egypt, à la Banque Impériale Ottomane, à la Bank of Egypt Ltd à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd, à la Banque de Salonique, à la Banco di Roma et au Crédit Lyonnais ou à Londres et à Paris à la Banque Impériale Ottomane op à Bruxelles au Siège des Tramways d'Alexandris, trois jours ad moins avant celui fixé pour l'Assemblée, et le reça qu'ils recevront en échange leur donnera le droit d'assister à l'Assemblée, soit per Formellement, soit par procuration. Alexandrie le 22 Décembre 1906.
PAR ORDRE : Le Directeur Général,
(S'goé) J.G. Jacot. 29162 1

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.
